Hi Everyone,
=A0
I'm doing some coursework which i'm basing in Sengoku per=
iod Japan on Oda Nobunaga. My current question is basically=A0"How successf=
ul was Oda Nobunaga at reunifying Japan".
=A0
Now the obvious answer and pr=
ossibly the right one is "very successful only "failed" because Nobunaga wa=
s overenthusiastic and Akechi made his famous cheap shot at power. However,=
 this essay needs to be coached in terms historiographical arguement and co=
mplaining. That just leaves me with just=A0Berry in english with her whole =
Hideyoshi-coaltion/Federalism arguement.
=A0
I would like to know if anyone=
 can link me to other arguments that Nobunaga was not so sucessful or that =
his success lacked the depth=A0or structures=A0needed to forge a long-lasti=
ng reunification settlement of the kind the Tokugawa achieved; even if he h=
ad lived longer. I've been looking at the usual suspects Berry, Lamers, Cam=
bridge History, etc. Recommendations or opinions of historians outside the =
English corpus of literature would be most appreciated.
=A0
PS: are any of =
the samurai archives forum admins out there, erm...your site is not=A0sendi=
ng me the confirmation email so I can post there. Please help!
-----------b=
ye bye------
